1W0301








[solution]		 _____ 1W0302








[solution]      [Next]
1W0303








[solution]		 _____ 1W0304








[solution]      [Next]
  • 1W0301
    • 1. Qxc5 black resigns! Note that
    • the pawn on d6 is pinned to the
    • queen by the rook on d1

    		_____
  • 1W0302
    • 1. Kf2 wins because he is attacking
    • the rook on e3
    • and the bishop on b7 at the same
    • time.

  • 1W0303
    • 1. Ne6 forks the Queen and Rook
    • (although the
    • position is complicated, white
    • should win.)

    		_____
  • 1W0304
    • 1. Bf4 skewers the Black Queen to
    • the bishop on d6
    • which is already attacked by the
    • queen on d1.

    1W0305








    [solution]    		 _____ 1W0306








    [solution]      [Next]
    1W0307








    [solution]    		 _____ 1W0308








    [solution]      [Next]
  • 1W0305
    • 1. Nd6+ or Nf6+ uncovers an attack on the
    • queen. Thanks to Vince
    • Deuel for surprising me with this
    • one.

    		_____
  • 1W0306
    • 1. Nd6+ creates a
    • discovered attack on the
    • queen at d5 by the queen on f3.
    • So the queen is lost

  • 1W0307
    • 1. Ne6 mate. Moving the knight
    • elsewhere does not work because
    • black can play Bd7. The double
    • check mates this work.

    		_____
  • 1W0308
    • 1. Nc4 attacks the Queen and
    • Bishop. Since the
    • Bishop is also attacked by the
    • bishop on f4, it will drop next
    • move.

    1W0309








    [solution]    		 _____ 1W0310








    [solution]      [Next]
  • 1W0309
    • The correct way is 1. Qa4+ with a
    • fork on the knight. The wrong way
    • would be 1. Nxe5 (Hoping to play
    • Qa4+ next move) Qa5+ refutes this
    • idea.

    		_____
  • 1W0310
    • 1. Nxe5+ wins the rook on c6. It
    • is a little more complicated than
    • that though. If Black responds 1.
    • ... Ke7 then both Rxc6 and Nxc6
    • win.
